note: one by Benjamin R. Foster (Before the Muses: An Anthology of 206 Further Reading
title: Ancient Mesopotamian Religion: A Descriptive Introduction (2015); and in the collection of selected essays by W.G. Lambert in Ancient Mesopotamian Religion and Mythology

Moving towards studies more focused upon Mesopotamian literary traditions: Stephanie Dalley’s Myths from Mesopotamia: Creation, The Flood, Gilgamesh, and Others (1989) provides a very readable entry point to the world of Akkadian myth

container-title: A combination of Sumerian and Akkadian poetry is the focus of Mesopotamian Poetic Language: Sumerian and Akkadian (1996
title: Sumerian love poetry provides the focus for Yitzhak Sefati’s Love Songs in Sumerian Literature: Critical Edition of the Dumuzi-Inanna Songs
A clearer understanding of Sumerian literary traditions can be developed through consultation with The World’s Oldest Literature: Studies in Sumerian Belles-Lettres
by William Hallo, and Jeremy Black’s comprehensive study Reading Sumerian Poetry
Jerrold S. Cooper has written several notable articles on particular aspects of Sumerian poetry and lamentations, a very small sample of which may be found in the bibliography of this book

To better understand the historical context of the poetry, the excellent 2013 volume, The Sumerian World (edited by Harriet Crawford) is recommended; the collection explores literary and archaeological evidence for political systems and everyday life (and death) as well as other diverse topics

unites the kind of overview useful for an introductory work, together with close attention to the Further Reading 207 sources and critical argumentation. Zainab Bahrani’s Women of Babylon (2001) provides a detailed insight into gender and sexuality in literature, and a strong analysis of the artistic sources for Mesopotamian women
Sex and Gender in the Ancient Near East

The myth of Inanna and Shukaletuda has formed the main focus of this chapter, and the definitive work on this myth, to date, is by Konrad Volk: Inanna and Šukaletuda: Zur historisch-politischen Deutung eines sumerischen Literaturwerkes
Jeffrey Cooley has made a thorough analysis of the astral associations of this myth (in English), and also provides a detailed bibliography for further study of the myth
For a thorough exploration of the differences between male and female divine creativity and fertility, see Stephanie Budin
Fertility and Gender in the Ancient Near East’

container-title: Politics, and the Ideology of Kingship in Ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia
title: Two articles are particularly relevant for considering the complex relationship between Ishtar/Inanna and the Mesopotamian king: these are Philip Jones’ ‘Embracing Inana: Legitimation and Mediation in the Ancient Mesopotamian Sacred Marriage Hymn Iddin-Dagan A’
and ‘King by Love of Inanna; An Image of Female Empowerment?
A recent book on kingship Experiencing Power, Generating Authority: Cosmos
Ishtar’s Proposal and Gilgamesh’s Refusal: An Interpretation of the Gilgamesh Epic, Tablet 6, Lines 1–79
